reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s Section 3 move of restricting attention to VNM-representable moral views and then defining “mostly-great” via cardinal thresholds, arguing this may bake in the kind of fine-grained tradeoffs that generate “fussiness.” That’s somewhat central to the *systematic* fussy-vs-easygoing taxonomy, but the overall “no easy eutopia” case also leans on earlier, more informal fragility/product-of-factors arguments, so undermining VNM assumptions wouldn’t collapse the whole position. The objection is plausible in outline (non-VNM views like incomparability/constraint-first/satisficing might avoid narrow numerical bands), but it’s not developed enough to show (i) these views are sufficiently plausible in this context, (ii) they actually yield “easy eutopia” rather than different forms of fussiness, or (iii) the authors’ argument can’t be reformulated in non-VNM terms; moreover the paper already flags that not all views satisfy completeness and uses VNM mainly as a representational convenience. Relevance is low because Forethought treats expected-value/VNM-style decision framing as a Tier 1 commitment; absent a substantially novel argument, this is largely a settled-premise challenge.
title: "The VNM Axioms Predetermine 'Fussiness'"
